awd_titl_txt: Elucidating Cell Signaling by Orthogonal Ubiquitin Transfer and Linkage-Specific di-Ubiquitin Probes
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division of NSF is funding Professor Jun Yin of the Georgia State University (GSU) and Professor Thomas A. Cropp of the Virginia Commonwealth University (VCU). The research seeks to understand the cell signaling mechanism carried out by by ubiquitin (UB). UB is a protein that is connected to other proteins in the cell to regulate cellular processes. Several different enzymes form a relay to transfer UB to cellular proteins. These transfers occur in response to the changes that occur within a cell. How these transfer enzymes select the targets of UB transfer is poorly understood. Consequently, the cell signaling networks that are aided by UB are vaguely defined. The team of Dr. Yin and Dr. Cropp is preparing and implementing probes to figure out the substrate profiles of key enzymes and their roles in cell biology. The investigators are also generating UB chains of defined linkages to investigate the catalytic mechanisms of the transfer enzymes. The project jointly trains undergraduate and graduate students to investigate the chemical basis of cell biology. By contributing to this project, the GSU and VCU students of diverse backgrounds obtain key research skills in chemistry, molecular biology, and cell biology. Integrated outreach programs provide research opportunities for middle school and high school students in underdeveloped communities in the Atlanta area. 

This joint project takes advantage of the orthogonal UB transfer (OUT) technology developed in the Yin laboratory and the unnatural amino acid (UAA) incorporation technology developed in the Cropp laboratory to study UB-mediated cell signaling. The Yin lab uses phage and yeast cell surface display to engineer OUT cascades of key E3s enzymes for cell regulation such as c-Cbl, Parkin, and E6AP.  The OUT cascades is expressed in the cell and proteomics is used to profile the substrates of specific E3s to reveal their biological functions. The Yin and Cropp labs synthesize di-UB conjugates of defined linkages by delivering UAA in various targeted positions in UB. The co-crystal structures of E2s with di-UB conjugates are determined in order to elucidate how E2s synthesize UB chains of diverse linkages. Overall the project provides much-needed insights in UB signaling networks and the chemical mechanism for "writing" the UB code.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: Georgia State University Research Foundation, Inc.
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: GEORGIA STATE UNIVERSITY RESEARCH FOUNDATION INC

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit          Ubiquitin (UB) is transferred through an E1-E2-E3 enzymatic cascade to the substrate proteins to regulate their stability and biological functions in the cell. The human genome encodes 2 E1s, 45 E2s, and more than 600 E3s. Together they assemble a complex network of UB transfer for the modification of cellular proteins. It has been shown that the two human E1 enzymes have overlapping yet distinct activities in transferring UB to various E2s. Each E2 interacts with multiple E3s, and each E3 can recognize multiple substrate proteins for UB modification. Furthermore, multiple E2s can pair with the same E3, and different E2-E3 pairs may attach UB chains of various lengths and linkages to the substrate proteins. Key questions are unsolved on how to identify ubiquitination targets of important E3s in order to map their positions in the cell signaling networks and how UB chains of specific linkages are assembled to encode unique signals in the cell.

 

We have developed a method that we refer to as “orthogonal UB transfer” (OUT) to untangle the complexity of protein ubiquitination networks. The key to OUT is to engineer a cascade composed of engineered E1, E2 and E3 enzymes (xE1, xE2 and xE3) that exclusively transfer an engineered UB (xUB) to the substrate of xE3.  Once we construct the OUT cascade, we would express xUB and the xE1-xE2-xE3 cascade enzymes in the cell and purify xUB-conjugated proteins with the affinity tags on xUB to identify potential E3 substrates by proteomics.

 

To implement OUT, we engineered pairwise interactions of xUB-xE1, xE1-xE2 and xE2-xE3 so that the engineered components would have exclusive interactions with each other for xUB transfer. Supported by NSF, we were able to generate OUT cascades with E3s of HECT, U-box, Ring, and RBR types. We then used the OUT screen to profile the substrate specificities of the E3s in HEK293 cells and mouse brain tissues. Based on the newly generated substrate profiles of various E3s, we discovered new pathways mediated by protein ubiquitination that regulate the host response to the infection of human papillomavirus, control protein modification by O-GlcNAc, activate the protein quality control systems counteracting prion assembly in yeast, and transduce cellular signals underpinning cell senescence and unfolded protein response. So our work has provided fundamental insights into the mechanism of cell regulation through UB transfer from E3 to the substrate proteins. In another part of the work supported by NSF, we synthesized linkage-specific di-ubiquitin (diUB) probes to mimic the binding modes of donor and acceptor UBs with the E2 enzyme at the moment of E2-catalyzed UB chain elongation. These diUB conjugates would allow us to elucidate the mechanism of E2s in their synthesis of UB chains of specific linkages. They can also function as reactivity-based probes to report the activity of deubiquitinating enzymes in the cell that would cleave the UB chains. 

 

Broader Impacts.          With the NSF support, we established an educational program that integrates research on ubiquitin signaling with classroom teaching to promote science education among high school, undergraduate, and graduate students. We designed an outreach program to train future scientists that are capable of conducting multidisciplinary research at the interface of chemistry and biology. From such a program, new courses covering research frontiers of Chemical Biology and Bioorganic Chemistry have been developed to teach students the latest discovery in life science based on methods breaking the traditional boundaries between chemistry and biology. Outside of the classroom, the program developed modules of experimental demonstrations and lectures that were carried by a Bio-Bus tour to the local high schools in Atlanta to enhance the learning experiences of the students in the STEM area. 

 


Last Modified: 11/18/2021
Modified by: Jun Yin
